original_title: Sri Lanka coal plant breaks down ahead of scheduled maintenance
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNExT – The third plant at Sri Lanka’s Norcocholai coal power complex suffered an outage head of scheduled maintenance in April, but there will be no power cuts, Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera said.

CEB has informed of a breakdown in unit 3 of Norochcholai power plant. Unit 3 was due to undergo major overhaul maintenance in April. To ensure an uninterrupted power supply, CEB owned Diesel & Fuel Oil Power plants will be used. There will be No power cuts due to the breakdown.
Maintenance of Sri Lanka’s coal plants were delayed after a currency crisis triggered by the island’s central bank in the course of mis-targeting interest rates.
Related; Sri Lanka tables controversial draft monetary law with multiple anchors
February and March are the driest months of the year where coal plants play the key role in energizing the country.
Currently the highest percentage of the power to the main grid is being generated by the coal power plant.
According to the CEB data, the coal power plant generate approximately 50 percent of the daily power needed while the thermal power plants generate 23 percent to the main grid. (Colombo/ Mar 19/2023)
